results.justification: The document explicitly states the research aims to extract CPS behaviors and predict learning outcomes using CSPM and predictive modeling. "Our work uses clustering and constraint-based sequential pattern mining (CSPM) to extract and analyze pedagogically relevant behavioral patterns..."
Sections 4.1-4.6 provide a detailed, step-by-step description of the study design, including data preprocessing, CSPM application, data representation, and predictive modeling.
The document does not state that the raw or processed datasets are publicly available.
While no data is shared, there is no explicit justification for why the data cannot be shared. However, the document does mention the small dataset size (61 samples) which could be a factor.

The document describes the data collected (in-game actions, timestamps, context name-value pairs) and the preprocessing steps (tokenization, lower-casing, cleaning, Word2Vec embedding, clustering). "These logs capture interactions such as movement...along with other miscellaneous data..."

The document clearly describes the data collection methods, stating that data was recorded from students’ in-game actions in EcoJourneys using semi-structured trace log files. "In EcoJourneys, we record students’ in-game actions in semi-structured trace log files."
The document does not state that the analysis code is shared in an open repository.
There is no justification provided for why the code cannot be shared.
While data preparation steps are described, the code used for these steps is not shared or mentioned.

Statistical tests (10-fold cross-validation, nested cross-validation), models (Logistic Regression, Elastic Net, Gradient Boosting, Logistic GAM), and assumptions are described. "We used 10-fold stratified cross-validation with 5-fold nested cross-validation..."
Accuracy and F1-score are reported as evaluation metrics. "It achieved an average accuracy of 70.4% and an F1-score of 68.2%."

Subjective context and interpretation are given when mapping clusters to CPS ontology codes and discussing the implications of the findings. "Our approach interprets the extracted patterns through pedagogical theory..."
The process of mapping clusters to CPS codes is described, providing insight into the analysis. "Clusters related to communication...were classified under the broad ‘social’ dimension..."
Results are presented in text and figures (Figures 4 and 5), clearly outlining the performance of different models. "For static features, Figure 4 presents the predictive performance of models..."

The document discusses limitations related to the small dataset size and the generalizability of the findings. "Our work utilizes data from only 61 students...making it difficult to generalize the conclusions..."
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration.
